title: Machine Learning
subtext: AI exists thanks to this
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Machine Learning
texts: Machine learning is a type of artificial intelligence that allows software applications to become more accurate at predicting outcomes without being explicitly programmed to do so. Machine learning algorithms use historical data as input to predict new output values.
It's used in many areas such as email filtering, network security, and computer vision.

title: Code Smell
subtext: Indicators that code might need improvement.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Code Smell
texts: A code smell is a sign in the code that something might be wrong. It doesn't mean the code is broken, but it suggests that it might be improved or fixed.
Think of it like noticing a weird smell in your house. It doesn't mean there's definitely a fire, but it's worth checking out.

title: Serverless Computing
subtext: Cloud computing without managing servers.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Serverless Computing
texts: Serverless computing is a cloud computing model where the cloud provider runs the server, and dynamically manages the allocation of machine resources. You don't have to worry about managing servers; you just focus on your code.
It's like renting a car instead of owning one. You get to use it when you need it without worrying about maintenance.

title: Optimistic Locking
subtext: Concurrency control method strategy.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Optimistic Locking
texts:
Optimistic locking is a strategy where you read a record and there is some versioning in it (can be timestamp, version number, etc), and then when you attempt to update the record, the versioning is checked. 
      The update is only committed when the record version remains the same. If the record version has changed, then the update attempt is aborted. 
      This is particularly useful to increase throughput, and prevent conflicts when multiple users attempt to update a single record.

It's like in an art class where everyone is coloring a big picture together, and each have their own copy to color. You start coloring your tree green, and your friend might color their tree as blue.
      When you finish, you check in the big picture if anyone has colored the tree. If no one has, you can add your green tree. But if someone has colored the tree, you can't just color over it. You have to decide together what color the tree should be.

title: Web Flow
subtext: The sequence of user steps on a website.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Web Flow
texts: Web flow refers to the sequence of steps or pages a user goes through on a website to complete a task. It's like a map that shows how users navigate your site.
Think of it like the steps you take when you follow a recipe to bake a cake.

title: Web Hooks
subtext: Automated messages between apps.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Web Hooks
texts: Web hooks are automated messages sent from one app to another when something happens. They let different applications communicate in real time.
It's like getting a text alert when your favorite show is on TV.

title: LLMs
subtext: AI systems for understanding and generating text.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: LLMs
texts: LLMs (Large Language Models) are advanced AI systems that can understand, generate, and interact with human language. They are trained on vast amounts of text data to perform a variety of language-related tasks.
Imagine a robot that has read all the books in the library and can talk about any topic.

title: Open Source
subtext: Software with publicly accessible source code.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Open Source
texts: Open source software is software with source code that anyone can inspect, modify, and enhance. It promotes collaboration and sharing among developers.
Think of it like a recipe that everyone can see, change, and improve.

title: Web Scraping
subtext: Automatically collecting data from websites.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Web Scraping
texts: Web scraping is the process of using software to automatically collect data from websites. It helps gather large amounts of information quickly.
It's like using a vacuum to clean up a room instead of picking up every piece of dust by hand.

title: Front End
subtext: The visual and interactive parts of a website.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Front End
texts: Front end development involves creating the parts of a website that users interact with. This includes everything you see and click on a website.
Think of it like decorating a cake. It's all about making it look good and making sure itâ€™s easy to enjoy.

title: Full Stack
subtext: Development of both front end and back end.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Full Stack
texts: Full stack development means working on both the front end (what users see) and the back end (the server and database) of a website or application. Full stack developers can build entire applications from start to finish.
It's like being able to bake a cake and decorate it too!

title: Functions
subtext: Reusable blocks of code performing specific tasks.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Functions
texts: Functions are blocks of code that perform specific tasks. You can call a function whenever you need to perform that task, which helps keep your code organized and reusable.
It's like having a set of instructions for making a sandwich. Anytime you want a sandwich, you just follow the steps.

title: Arguments
subtext: Values passed to functions to influence their behavior.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Arguments
texts: Arguments are the values you pass to a function so it can perform its task. They are like the ingredients you give to a recipe.
Think of it like telling a function to make a sandwich and giving it bread, peanut butter, and jelly.

title: Dictionary
subtext: A collection of key-value pairs in programming.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Dictionary
texts: A dictionary in programming is a collection of key-value pairs. It's like a real dictionary where you look up a word (key) to find its definition (value).
Imagine having a box with labels (keys) and items (values) inside. You can quickly find what you need by looking at the labels.

title: Tuple
subtext: An ordered, unchangeable collection of items.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Tuple
texts: A tuple is a collection of items that are ordered and unchangeable. It's like a list, but once you create it, you can't change it.
Think of it like a grocery list written in pen. You can't erase or change the items once they're written down.

title: List
subtext: An ordered, changeable collection of items.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: List
texts: A list is a collection of items that are ordered and changeable. You can add, remove, or change items in a list.
Imagine a grocery list written in pencil. You can add new items, erase old ones, or change them as you need.

title: Boolean
subtext: A data type with true or false values.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Boolean
texts: A boolean is a data type with two possible values: true or false. It's like a light switch that can only be on or off.
Think of it like asking a yes or no question. The answer can only be yes (true) or no (false).

title: String
subtext: A sequence of characters representing text.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: String
texts: A string is a sequence of characters, like letters, numbers, and symbols, used to represent text in programming.
Imagine a string as a necklace made of different beads. Each bead is a character in the string.

title: Floats
subtext: Numbers with decimal points for precision.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Floats
texts: Floats are numbers that have a decimal point. They can represent fractions and very precise values.
Think of a float as the way you write money, like $3.50 or $7.99.

title: Double
subtext: More precise and larger decimal numbers.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Double
texts: A double is similar to a float, but it can store much larger and more precise decimal numbers.
Imagine a double as a super accurate float, used when you need extra precision, like in scientific calculations.

title: Data Types
subtext: Categories defining the kind of data variables can hold.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Types
texts: Data types define the kind of data a variable can hold. Common data types include integers (whole numbers), floats (decimal numbers), strings (text), and booleans (true or false).
Think of data types like different kinds of containers: a jar for jam, a box for toys, or a bottle for water.

title: Threads
subtext: Mini-programs running concurrently within a larger program.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Threads
texts: Threads are like mini-programs running inside a larger program. They allow different parts of the program to run simultaneously.
Imagine a restaurant kitchen where multiple chefs (threads) are preparing different dishes at the same time.

title: Classes
subtext: Blueprints for creating objects with defined properties and behaviors.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Classes
texts: Classes are blueprints for creating objects in programming. They define the properties and behaviors that the objects created from the class will have.
Think of a class as a cookie cutter and the objects as the cookies made from it.

title: Objects
subtext: Instances of classes with specific attributes and methods.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Objects
texts: Objects are instances of classes. They have the properties and behaviors defined by their class.
Imagine an object as a specific cookie made from a cookie cutter. It has the same shape but can be decorated differently.

title: Inheritance
subtext: Creating new classes from existing ones, inheriting their properties and behaviors.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Inheritance
texts: Inheritance is a way to create a new class using details from an existing class. The new class inherits the properties and behaviors of the existing class.
Think of inheritance like getting traits from your parents, like eye color or hair color.

title: Syntax
subtext: Rules defining the structure and format of code.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Syntax
texts: Syntax in programming refers to the rules that define the structure of a program. Itâ€™s like grammar in a language, ensuring that code is written correctly so the computer can understand it.
Imagine syntax as the rules of writing sentences in English, like using proper punctuation and word order.

title: IDE
subtext: Integrated Development Environment for coding and debugging.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: IDE (Integrated Development Environment)
texts: An IDE is a software application that provides tools to help programmers write, test, and debug their code. Itâ€™s like a supercharged text editor with features like syntax highlighting, code completion, and debugging.
Think of an IDE as a toolkit for coding, with everything you need in one place.

title: Debugger
subtext: Tool for finding and fixing code errors
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Debugger
texts: A debugger is a tool that helps programmers find and fix bugs (errors) in their code. It allows you to run your code step-by-step to see whatâ€™s happening at each stage.
Imagine a debugger like a magnifying glass that helps you see exactly where things go wrong in a program.

title: Deployment
subtext: Making applications available for use
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Deployment
texts: Deployment is the process of making an application available for use. This involves moving the code from development to a live environment where users can access it.
Think of deployment like launching a new video game, making it available for everyone to play.

title: Continuous Deployment
subtext: Automatic deployment of code changes
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Continuous Deployment
texts: Continuous Deployment is a software release process that automatically deploys every code change that passes automated tests to production. It ensures that the software is always up-to-date and can be quickly updated.
Imagine Continuous Deployment as a bakery where fresh bread is baked and put on shelves as soon as it's ready, ensuring customers always get the freshest products.

title: Deployment Pipeline
subtext: Automated process for software changes
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Deployment Pipeline
texts: A deployment pipeline is a set of automated processes that ensure software changes go through various stages like building, testing, and deployment. It helps deliver high-quality software quickly and consistently.
Think of a deployment pipeline like an assembly line in a factory, where each step ensures the product is perfect before it reaches the customer.

title: Data Validation
subtext: Ensuring data accuracy and completeness
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Validation
texts: Data validation is the process of checking data for accuracy and completeness before using it. This ensures that the data is correct and reliable.
Imagine data validation like checking your homework for mistakes before submitting it to your teacher.

title: Data Serialization
subtext: Converting data for storage or transmission
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Serialization
texts: Data serialization is the process of converting data into a format that can be easily stored or transmitted and then reconstructed later. Common formats include JSON and XML.
Think of data serialization like packing a suitcase for a trip, making it easy to carry and unpack later.

title: Mocking
subtext: Creating fake objects for testing
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Mocking
texts: Mocking is a technique in software testing where you create fake versions of objects or functions to test parts of your code without relying on the real ones.
Imagine mocking like practicing a play with stand-ins before the actual actors come in.

title: Authentication
subtext: Verifying user identity
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Authentication
texts: Authentication is the process of verifying who someone is. Itâ€™s like showing your ID to prove your identity.
Think of authentication as logging into your email account using your username and password to prove itâ€™s really you.

title: Authorization
subtext: Determining user permissions
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Authorization
texts: Authorization is the process of determining what someone is allowed to do. It happens after authentication.
Think of authorization like a security guard checking if you have access to a VIP area after youâ€™ve shown your ID.

title: Prototypes (Software Development)
subtext: Early models of software for testing
author: Buzzpy

title: Monolithic Architecture
subtext: Integrated large system design
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Monolithic Architecture
texts: Monolithic architecture is a software design where all the components of the application are integrated into a single, large system.
Imagine monolithic architecture like a giant block of Legos all stuck together, where changing one part affects the entire structure.

title: GitHub
subtext: Platform for code hosting and collaboration
author: Buzzpy

description.title: GitHub
texts: GitHub is a platform that allows developers to host, review, and manage their code. Itâ€™s a place where you can collaborate with others on software projects.
Think of GitHub like a social network for programmers where they share and improve each otherâ€™s code.

title: ORM (Object-Relational Mapping)
subtext: Mapping database tables to objects
author: Buzzpy

title: Caching
subtext: Storing data for quick access
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Caching
texts: Caching is a technique used to store copies of frequently accessed data in a temporary storage area, or cache, so that it can be accessed more quickly.
Think of caching like keeping your favorite snacks in a drawer so you donâ€™t have to go to the kitchen every time youâ€™re hungry.

title: Deep Learning
subtext: A subset of machine learning
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Deep Learning
texts: Deep learning is a subset of machine learning where artificial neural networks, algorithms inspired by the human brain, learn from large amounts of data. It's a key technology behind driverless cars, enabling them to recognize a stop sign, or to distinguish a pedestrian from a lamppost.
Deep learning is used in many applications such as voice assistants, translation services, and image recognition.

title: Artificial Intelligence
subtext: A frenemy
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Artificial Intelligence
texts: Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think like humans and mimic their actions. The term may also be applied to any machine that exhibits traits associated with a human mind such as learning and problem-solving.
AI is used in many areas such as robotics, autonomous vehicles, and natural language processing.

title: Cybersecurity
subtext: Staying secured in a a world of hackers
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Cybersecurity
texts: Cybersecurity involves protecting computer systems and networks from digital attacks, theft, and damage. It includes various practices and technologies to safeguard data and maintain privacy.
Cybersecurity is crucial for protecting sensitive information and ensuring the safe operation of systems in both personal and professional environments.

title: Epochs
subtext: Training rounds in Machine Learning
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Epochs
texts: In machine learning, an epoch is one complete pass through the entire training dataset. During each epoch, the model's parameters are updated to improve accuracy.

Multiple epochs are often needed for a model to learn effectively and reach high performance on the task it is trained for. However, its' crucial to determine the number of epochs carefully, as explaned in the image below.

title: APIs
subtext: Application Programming Interfaces
author: Buzzpy

description.title: APIs
texts: An API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of rules that allows different software programs to communicate with each other. It defines how requests and responses should be formatted so that different systems can interact seamlessly.
APIs are used to integrate different services, enabling developers to build applications that interact with other software or services.

title: Cloud Computing
subtext: It's always fun on the clouds, until it starts "leaking"
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Cloud Computing
texts: Cloud computing is the delivery of computing servicesâ€”such as servers, storage, databases, and softwareâ€”over the internet (the cloud). It allows users to access and use these services without having to manage physical servers or infrastructure.
Cloud computing provides flexibility, scalability, and cost-efficiency for businesses and individuals. Following image shows types of cloud computing

title: Data Science
subtext: Science of converting information to Data
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Science
texts: Data science involves using scientific methods, processes, and systems to extract insights and knowledge from data. It combines various fields such as statistics, data analysis, and machine learning to understand and interpret complex data.
Data science helps in making informed decisions and predictions based on data analysis.

title: Quantum Computing
subtext: Sheldon Cooper's gonna love this
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Quantum Computing
texts: Quantum computing is an area of computing that uses principles of quantum mechanics to perform calculations. It leverages quantum bits (qubits) to process information in ways that classical computers cannot.
Quantum computing has the potential to solve complex problems more efficiently than traditional computers.

title: Internet of Things
subtext: A Network of things
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Internet of Things
texts: The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the network of physical objects embedded with sensors and software that can connect and exchange data with other devices over the internet.
IoT enables smarter interactions between devices and can be used in various applications like smart homes, health monitoring, and industrial automation.

title: Blockchain
subtext: A chain of transactions
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Blockchain
texts: Blockchain is a digital ledger technology that records transactions across many computers in a way that ensures the security and transparency of the data.
Each transaction is recorded in a "block," and blocks are linked together in a "chain." Blockchain is used in cryptocurrencies and other applications requiring secure data storage.

title: ReactJS
subtext: A popular JS library for building user-interfaces
author: Buzzpy

title: Docker
subtext: The most popular Container tool
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Docker
texts: Docker is a platform that allows developers to package applications and their dependencies into containers. Containers are lightweight, portable, and can run on any system with Docker installed.
Docker simplifies deployment and scaling of applications, ensuring consistency across different environments.

title: The __init__ Function
subtext: A special method in Python Programming Language
author: Buzzpy

title: Three-Sigma Rule
subtext: A rule of thumb in data science
author: Buzzpy

title: Recursion
subtext: A programming technique
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Recursion
texts: Recursion is a programming technique where a function calls itself in order to solve a problem. It is often used to break down complex problems into simpler sub-problems.
Recursion is useful in tasks such as tree traversal, sorting algorithms, and solving mathematical problems.

title: Iteration
subtext: A programming technique
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Iteration
texts: Iteration is the process of repeating a set of operations or instructions in software development, refining the outcome with each cycle.
Think of iteration as a loop where each pass brings you closer to the perfect solution, whether it's fine-tuning code or improving a machine learning model.

title: Version Control
subtext: Recording every change
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Version Control
texts: Version control is a system that records changes to files over time so that you can recall specific versions later. It is essential for managing software development and tracking changes to code.

Version control helps coordinate work among multiple developers and track the history of changes. Mainly, there are two types of version control systems as "Centralized" and "Distributed" Version Control Systems, as explained in the image below.

title: Git
subtext: The most popular version control system
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Git
texts: Git is a version control system that tracks changes to files and allows multiple people to collaborate on a project. It helps manage code changes, track history, and resolve conflicts.
Git is widely used in software development to maintain code integrity and support collaborative work.

title: Microservices
subtext: Independent services working together
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Microservices
texts: Microservices is a way of designing software systems where the application is divided into small, independent services that work together. Each service performs a specific function and can be developed, deployed, and scaled independently.
Think of microservices like a team of specialists. Each specialist is very good at one thing. They work independently, but they all come together to complete a big project.

title: RESTful API
subtext: API using standard HTTP methods
author: Buzzpy

title: GraphQL
subtext: Query language for APIs
author: Buzzpy

description.title: GraphQL
texts: GraphQL is a query language for APIs that allows clients to request exactly the data they need. It provides a more efficient and flexible alternative to RESTful APIs.
Imagine being able to ask for specific ingredients in a recipe, rather than getting the entire cookbook.

title: Containerization
subtext: Packaging applications for consistent deployment
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Containerization
texts: Containerization is a technology that packages an application and its dependencies into a "container" that can run anywhere. Containers make it easy to deploy and manage applications consistently across different environments.
Think of it like packing everything you need for a trip into a single, portable box.

title: Kubernetes
subtext: Platform for automating container management
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Kubernetes
texts: Kubernetes is an open-source platform designed to automate the deployment, scaling, and operation of containerized applications. It helps manage clusters of containers.
Think of it as the conductor of an orchestra, ensuring all the musicians (containers) play in harmony.

title: Branching
subtext: Creating separate code versions
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Branching
texts: Branching is a feature of version control systems like Git that allows developers to create separate copies of the codebase to work on different tasks without affecting the main project.
It's like having different drafts of an essay where you can make changes without messing up the original.

title: Merging
subtext: Combining changes from branches
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Merging
texts: Merging is the process of combining changes from different branches into a single branch in version control systems. It helps integrate features and fixes back into the main codebase.
It's like combining different drafts of an essay into one final version.

title: Pull Requests (PR)
subtext: Proposing and reviewing code changes
author: Buzzpy

title: Code Review
subtext: Checking code for quality and improvement
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Code Review
texts: Code review is the process where developers check each other's code for mistakes, improvements, and learning opportunities. It ensures code quality and helps share knowledge within the team.
Think of it as having a friend read your essay to catch any errors and suggest better ways to write it.

title: Refactoring
subtext: Improving code structure without changing behavior
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Refactoring
texts: Refactoring is the process of improving the structure and readability of code without changing its behavior. It's like cleaning and organizing your room to make it more efficient and pleasant to use.
Imagine rewriting a messy essay to make it clearer and easier to understand.

title: Technical Debt
subtext: Extra work due to past shortcuts
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Technical Debt
texts: Technical debt refers to the extra work required in the future because of shortcuts or suboptimal solutions made in the past. It's like doing your homework quickly and poorly, knowing you'll have to redo it later.
Think of it as borrowing time now but paying back with interest later.

title: Design Patterns
subtext: Standard solutions to common design problems
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Design Patterns
texts: Design patterns are standard solutions to common problems in software design. They provide a reusable template for solving recurring issues in coding.
It's like having a recipe for your favorite dish that you can use over and over again.

title: SOLID Principles
subtext: Guidelines for better software design
author: Buzzpy

description.title: SOLID Principles
texts: SOLID principles are a set of guidelines to make software design more understandable, flexible, and maintainable. They stand for Single Responsibility, Open/Closed, Liskov Substitution, Interface Segregation, and Dependency Inversion.
Think of them as rules for writing good, clean, and efficient code.

title: KISS Principle
subtext: Keep it simple to avoid complexity
author: Buzzpy

description.title: KISS Principle
texts: The KISS principle stands for "Keep It Simple, Stupid." It means that systems should be as simple as possible to avoid unnecessary complexity.
Think of it like writing an essay in clear, straightforward language so everyone can understand it easily.

title: DRY Principle
subtext: Avoid code repetition
author: Buzzpy

description.title: DRY Principle
texts: The DRY principle stands for "Don't Repeat Yourself." It means that every piece of knowledge or logic should be written once and reused throughout the code.
Think of it like using the same recipe card for your favorite dish instead of writing a new one each time.

title: Agile
subtext: A methology in Software Development
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Agile
texts: Agile is a methodology for software development that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, and customer feedback. It focuses on delivering small, incremental improvements to a project.
Agile methodologies include frameworks such as Scrum and Kanban, which help teams adapt to changes and continuously improve their processes.

title: Scrum
subtext: A framework within the Agile methodology
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Scrum
texts: Scrum is a framework within the Agile methodology used for managing and completing complex projects. It involves iterative development and regular feedback from stakeholders.
Scrum emphasizes teamwork, accountability, and continuous improvement through practices such as sprints, daily stand-ups, and retrospectives.

title: Kanban
subtext: A visual workflow management method
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Kanban
texts: Kanban is a visual workflow management method that helps teams visualize and manage work. It uses a board with columns to represent different stages of the work process.
Kanban helps teams improve efficiency by limiting work in progress and optimizing the flow of tasks through the workflow.

title: HTML
subtext: HyperText Markup Language
author: Buzzpy

description.title: HTML
texts: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the standard language used to create and design web pages. It structures content on the web by using tags and elements to define headings, paragraphs, links, images, and other components.
HTML forms the backbone of web content and is used in conjunction with CSS and JavaScript to build complete web pages.

title: CSS
subtext: Cascading Style Sheets
author: Buzzpy

description.title: CSS
texts: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of a document written in HTML. It controls the layout, colors, fonts, and overall design of web pages.
CSS allows for the separation of content and design, making web pages more flexible and easier to maintain.

title: Java
subtext: A high-level programming-language
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Java
texts: Java is a high-level programming language known for its portability, scalability, and performance. It is widely used for building enterprise-level applications, mobile apps, and web services.
Java's "write once, run anywhere" philosophy makes it a popular choice for cross-platform development.

title: C#
subtext: A modern, OOP language from Microsoft
author: Buzzpy

title: Ruby
subtext: Another simple, OOP language
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Ruby
texts: Ruby is an object-oriented programming language known for its simplicity and productivity. It is often used for web development, particularly with the Ruby on Rails framework.
Ruby's elegant syntax makes it easy to read and write, helping developers create robust applications quickly.

title: Swift
subtext: A programming language from Apple
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Swift
texts: Swift is a programming language developed by Apple for iOS and macOS development. It is known for its speed, safety, and ease of use.
Swift allows developers to build high-performance applications with modern features and a clean syntax.

title: Typescript
subtext: A superset of JavaScript
author: Buzzpy

description.title: TypeScript
texts: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds static typing to the language. It helps developers catch errors early and improve code quality by providing type-checking and advanced features.
TypeScript is compiled to JavaScript and is compatible with existing JavaScript code and libraries.

title: Kotlin
subtext: A statically-typed programming language by JetBrains
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Kotlin
texts: Kotlin is a statically-typed programming language developed by JetBrains. It is used for Android development and is fully interoperable with Java.
Kotlin offers modern features, concise syntax, and improved safety compared to Java.

title: Bash
subtext: A unix shell and command language
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Bash
texts: Bash is a Unix shell and command language used for writing shell scripts. It allows users to automate tasks, manage files, and interact with the operating system through commands.
Bash scripts are commonly used for system administration and software deployment tasks.

title: Ruby on Rails
subtext: A web application framework written in Ruby
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Ruby on Rails
texts: Ruby on Rails is a web application framework written in Ruby. It follows the Model-View-Controller (MVC) architecture and emphasizes convention over configuration.
Rails helps developers build robust and scalable web applications quickly by providing built-in tools and best practices.

title: Angular
subtext: A TypeScript-based web application framework
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Angular
texts: Angular is a TypeScript-based open-source web application framework developed by Google. It provides a comprehensive solution for building dynamic and responsive web applications.
Angular includes features such as data binding, dependency injection, and modular development to streamline the development process.

title: VueJS
subtext: A aggressive progressive JavaScript framework
author: Buzzpy

title: Flutter
subtext: An UI toolkit from Google
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Flutter
texts: Flutter is an open-source UI toolkit developed by Google for building natively compiled applications for mobile, web, and desktop from a single codebase.
Flutter uses the Dart programming language and provides a rich set of pre-designed widgets and tools for creating beautiful and responsive user interfaces.

title: SwiftUI
subtext: Another framework from Apple
author: Buzzpy

title: Data Structure
subtext: A way of oragnzing and storing data
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Structure
texts: A data structure is a way of organizing and storing data so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently. Common data structures include arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, and trees.
Choosing the right data structure is crucial for optimizing performance and managing data effectively in software applications.

title: Big O Notation
subtext: A term used to explain... algorithms?
author: Buzzpy

title: Recursion Depth
subtext: Used to elaborate on recusrion method
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Recursion Depth
texts: Recursion depth refers to the number of times a recursive function calls itself before reaching the base case. It is important to manage recursion depth to avoid stack overflow errors and ensure efficient execution.
Understanding recursion depth helps in designing algorithms that use recursion effectively and safely.

title: Debugging
subtext: An interesting process that makes programmers yell "Just Why!?"
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Debugging
texts: Debugging is the process of identifying and fixing errors or bugs in software code. It involves testing, analyzing, and modifying code to ensure that it functions correctly.
Effective debugging is crucial for improving software quality and performance.

title: Testing
subtext: The ultimate fear of developers
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Testing
texts: Testing is the process of evaluating software to ensure it behaves as expected. It involves executing code with various inputs to verify correctness, performance, and reliability.
Testing can be performed manually or through automated test scripts and is essential for delivering high-quality software.

title: Unit test
subtext: A type of testing
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Unit Test
texts: A unit test is a type of testing that focuses on verifying individual components or functions of a software application. It ensures that each unit of code performs as intended.
Unit tests are typically automated and help identify bugs early in the development process.

title: Integration Test
subtext: Another type of testing
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Integration Test
texts: Integration testing focuses on verifying the interactions between different components or systems to ensure they work together as expected.
Integration tests help ensure that different parts of a software application integrate smoothly and function correctly as a whole.

title: End-to-End Test
subtext: Another type of testing
author: Buzzpy

title: Performence Test
subtext: A type of testing focusing on applcation performence
author: Buzzpy

title: Load Test
subtext: A type of performance testing
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Load Test
texts: Load testing is a type of performance testing that evaluates how a software application handles a specific volume of users or transactions.
It helps determine if the application can handle expected load conditions without degrading performance.

title: Stress Test
subtext: A type of performance testing under pressure
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Stress Test
texts: Stress testing assesses how a software application performs under extreme conditions, such as a sudden spike in user activity or data volume.
It helps identify the application's breaking point and ensure it can recover gracefully from high-stress situations.

title: Security Test
subtext: A test against hacking and whatnot
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Security Test
texts: Security testing identifies vulnerabilities and weaknesses in a software application to ensure it is protected against potential threats and attacks.
It involves checking for issues such as unauthorized access, data breaches, and compliance with security standards.

title: Usability Test
subtext: A test that ensures that application is user-friendly
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Usability Test
texts: Usability testing evaluates how easy and intuitive a software application is for users. It focuses on user experience, including ease of navigation, accessibility, and overall satisfaction.
Usability tests help ensure that the application is user-friendly and meets the needs of its target audience.

title: User-Acceptance Test (UAT)
subtext: Final user testing phase
author: Buzzpy

title: Test-Driven Development
subtext: Or TDD, a software development approach
author: Buzzpy

title: Continuous Integration (CI)
subtext: A software development practice
author: Buzzpy

title: Continuous Delivery (CD)
subtext: A software development practice often implemented with CI
author: Buzzpy

title: DevOps
subtext: A set of practices that combine Dev and Ops
author: Buzzpy

title: SQL
subtext: A relational database management system
author: Buzzpy

description.title: SQL
texts: SQL (Structured Query Language) is a language used for managing and querying relational databases. It allows users to perform operations such as retrieving, inserting, updating, and deleting data.
SQL is essential for working with databases and is widely used in various applications to interact with data.

title: NoSQL
subtext: A non-relational database management system
author: Buzzpy

description.title: NoSQL
texts: NoSQL is a type of database that provides a mechanism for data storage and retrieval that is different from traditional relational databases. It is designed to handle large volumes of unstructured or semi-structured data.
NoSQL databases are often used for applications that require high scalability, performance, and flexibility in handling data.

title: Logistic Regression
subtext: Predicts probabilities for binary outcomes.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Logistic Regression
texts: Logistic regression is a statistical method used for binary classification. It helps predict the probability of an outcome that can be one of two possible categories. For example, it might predict whether an email is spam or not spam based on its content.
It works by fitting a logistic curve to the data and using this curve to make predictions.

title: K-Means Clustering
subtext: Groups data into clusters based on similarity.
author: Buzzpy

title: Decision Trees
subtext: Uses a tree-like model of decisions and their possible consequences.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Decision Trees
texts: Decision Trees are a type of algorithm used for classification and regression tasks. They split data into branches to make decisions based on various features, much like a flowchart.
For instance, they can help determine whether a loan should be approved based on applicant details.

title: Random Forest
subtext: Combines multiple decision trees to improve accuracy.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Random Forest
texts: Random Forest is an ensemble learning technique that combines multiple decision trees to improve prediction accuracy. Each tree makes a decision, and the majority vote determines the final outcome.
It's like having a group of experts where the decision is based on the consensus of all experts.

title: Support Vector Machines
subtext: Finds the best boundary between classes in data.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Support Vector Machines
texts: Support Vector Machines (SVM) are a type of supervised learning algorithm used for classification and regression. They work by finding the best boundary that separates different classes of data points.
Imagine drawing a line that best divides two groups of points on a graph. SVM finds this optimal line.

title: Gradient Descent
subtext: Optimizes model parameters by minimizing errors.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Gradient Descent
texts: Gradient Descent is an optimization algorithm used to minimize the error of a model. It works by iteratively adjusting the model's parameters to find the lowest error value.
Think of it as climbing down a hill to reach the lowest point, which represents the smallest error.

title: Neural Networks
subtext: Mimics the human brain to recognize patterns and make predictions.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Neural Networks
texts: Neural Networks are a set of algorithms modeled after the human brain. They consist of interconnected nodes (neurons) that work together to solve complex problems, like image recognition.
They can learn from data and make predictions, just like how our brains learn from experience.

title: gRPC
subtext: A high-performance framework for service communication
author: Buzzpy

title: Dependency Graph
subtext: Visualize dependencies in systems or projects
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Dependency Graph
texts: A dependency graph is a tool that helps visualize dependencies in systems or projects, showing how different elements are interconnected.
Imagine a dependency graph as a map that shows which city roads are connected to which, helping you plan your travel efficiently.

title: Cluster Computing
subtext: Connecting multiple computers to work as a single system
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Cluster Computing
texts: Cluster computing involves connecting multiple computers to work as a single system, enhancing computing strength and reliability.
Think of cluster computing as a team of horses pulling a wagon, where the load is shared and the journey is faster.

title: Message Queues
subtext: Manage asynchronous communication between processes
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Message Queues
texts: Message queues help applications communicate and process operations asynchronously, managing data exchange between different processes or services.
Imagine a message queue as a series of post office boxes, where messages wait safely until their recipient is ready to process them.

title: Rate Limiting
subtext: Control the frequency of resource access to prevent overuse
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Rate Limiting
texts: Rate limiting controls how often a user or system can access a resource or perform an action, preventing overuse and ensuring fair usage.
Think of rate limiting as traffic lights on the internet, controlling the flow to prevent congestion.

title: Concurrency
subtext: Run multiple processes simultaneously for efficiency
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Concurrency
texts: Concurrency in computing allows multiple processes to run simultaneously within the same application, enhancing efficiency.
Imagine concurrency as a kitchen where several chefs prepare different parts of a meal at the same time.

title: Vertical Scaling
subtext: Increase the capacity of a single server
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Vertical Scaling
texts: Vertical scaling, or scaling up, involves increasing the capacity of a single server or resource without adding more physical units.
Think of vertical scaling like upgrading a car's engine to increase speed and performance instead of adding more cars.

title: Horizontal Scaling
subtext: Add more machines to handle increased load
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Horizontal Scaling
texts: Horizontal scaling, or scaling out, involves adding more machines or resources to a pool to handle increased load.
Imagine horizontal scaling as adding more lanes to a highway to accommodate more traffic.

title: Database Indexing
subtext: Improve data retrieval speed in databases
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Database Indexing
texts: Database indexing improves the speed of data retrieval operations by efficiently locating and accessing the data within a database.
Think of database indexing like an index in a book, helping you find information quickly without scanning every page.

title: Data Replication
subtext: Copy data to ensure consistency and accessibility
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Replication
texts: Data replication involves copying data from one location to another to ensure consistency and support data recovery and accessibility.
Think of data replication like having multiple copies of a document in different locations, so if one is lost, others are still available.

title: ACID Transactions
subtext: Ensure reliability in database operations
author: Buzzpy

description.title: ACID Transactions
texts: ACID (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) transactions ensure that database operations are processed reliably.
Think of ACID transactions as a checklist that guarantees every financial transaction is processed completely and accurately.

title: Eventually Consistent Systems
subtext: Systems that eventually reach consistency over time
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Eventually Consistent Systems
texts: Eventually consistent systems are a model of consistency in distributed computing where the system eventually reaches consistency but does not guarantee immediate consistency.

title: Memory Leaks
subtext: Issues in memory management that can cause system crashes
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Memory Leaks
texts: Memory leaks occur when a computer program incorrectly manages memory allocations, resulting in reduced performance or system crashes.

title: Namespace
subtext: Organize code to avoid naming conflicts
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Namespace
texts: A namespace is a declarative region that provides a scope to the identifiers (the names of types, functions, variables, etc) inside it.

title: Service Discovery
subtext: Dynamic directory for services to find each other
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Service Discovery
texts: Service discovery is a dynamic directory that helps services find and communicate with each other in cloud environments.
Think of service discovery as the phonebook for services, allowing them to look up how to connect with other services dynamically.

title: Throttling
subtext: Control network traffic to prevent overloading
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Throttling
texts: Throttling is a technique used to control the amount of traffic sent or received on a network to prevent overloading.
Imagine throttling as a traffic light controlling the flow of cars to prevent congestion.

title: Function as a Service (FaaS)
subtext: Execute code without managing infrastructure
author: Buzzpy

title: Data Lakehouse
subtext: Combine data lakes and warehouses for comprehensive storage
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Lakehouse
texts: A Data Lakehouse combines the features of data lakes and data warehouses to provide structured and unstructured data storage and analytics capabilities.
Think of a Data Lakehouse as a hybrid home that offers both the vast storage space of a warehouse and the relaxing, fluid environment of a lake.

title: Event Loop
subtext: Programming construct that waits for and dispatches events
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Event Loop
texts: The event loop is a programming construct that waits for and dispatches events or messages in a program.
Imagine the event loop as a postal worker sorting and delivering mail as it arrives, ensuring that each message reaches its destination promptly.

title: Tokenization
subtext: Convert sensitive data into non-sensitive tokens
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Tokenization
texts: Tokenization is the process of converting sensitive data into non-sensitive data called tokens, which can be used in a database or internal system without exposing sensitive information.
Think of tokenization as swapping out your real, valuable diamonds for costume jewelry when traveling to secure the real assets.

title: Server Sent Events (SSE)
subtext: Automatically update web pages with server data
author: Buzzpy

title: Message Brokers
subtext: Intermediaries that manage communication between apps
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Message Brokers
texts: Message brokers are intermediaries that manage communication and data exchange between different software applications.
Think of message brokers as post offices, ensuring that messages are delivered from one application to another without them needing to communicate directly.

title: Cache Invalidation
subtext: Remove outdated data to make room for fresh information
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Cache Invalidation
texts: Cache invalidation is the process of removing outdated data from cache so that fresh data can be loaded the next time it is needed.
Think of cache invalidation like cleaning out your fridge; you need to remove old food to make room for fresh groceries.

title: Immutable Data Structures
subtext: Data structures that cannot be modified after creation
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Immutable Data Structures
texts: Immutable data structures are data structures that cannot be modified after they are created.
Imagine immutable data structures as a written contract; once it's signed, it cannot be changed, only replaced with a new version.

title: Data Deduplication
subtext: Eliminate redundant data to increase storage efficiency
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Deduplication
texts: Data deduplication is a technique used to eliminate redundant copies of data, increasing storage efficiency.
Think of data deduplication as decluttering your digital storage by removing unnecessary duplicates of your files.

title: Stateful vs Stateless Systems
subtext: Compare systems that maintain state with those that don't
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Stateful vs Stateless Systems
texts: In stateful systems, the server stores information about the client's session. Stateless systems do not store this data, treating each request as independent.
Imagine stateful systems as having a memory of past interactions, whereas stateless systems have no recollection of previous encounters.

title: Zero Downtime Deployment
subtext: Update software without causing service disruption
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Zero Downtime Deployment
texts: Zero downtime deployment refers to the process of updating software without causing any service disruption or downtime.
Think of it as renovating a bridge while keeping it open to traffic.

title: Data Partitioning
subtext: Divide a database into distinct, independent parts
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Partitioning
texts: Data partitioning involves dividing a database into distinct, independent parts to improve manageability, performance, and availability.
Imagine data partitioning as organizing a library into separate rooms, each holding different genres of books.

title: Feature Branching
subtext: Isolate development in branches for easier integration
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Feature Branching
texts: Feature branching is a version control strategy where developers create a branch for each new feature, isolating development and making integration easier.
Think of feature branching as setting up individual workstations for each project in a workshop.

title: Deadlock
subtext: A stand-off where processes block each other's progress
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Deadlock
texts: Deadlock is a situation in computing where two or more processes are each waiting for the other to release a resource, causing all of them to remain blocked.
Imagine deadlock as a stand-off in a narrow hallway where two people block each other's way and neither can move forward until one steps aside.

title: Micro-batching
subtext: Process small groups of data in short intervals
author: Buzzpy

title: Domain-Driven Design
subtext: Software development approach focused on core business concepts
author: Buzzpy

title: API Versioning
subtext: Manage API changes by assigning version numbers
author: Buzzpy

description.title: API Versioning
texts: API Versioning is the process of assigning version numbers to different stages of API development to manage changes and ensure backward compatibility.
Imagine API versioning as a way of keeping a diary of changes to a recipe, allowing you to refer back to any version at any time.

title: Distributed File System (DFS)
subtext: A network file system that spans multiple servers
author: Buzzpy

title: Stateful Widget
subtext: UI component that maintains state across sessions
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Stateful Widget
texts: A Stateful Widget in UI programming is a component that maintains state data across user sessions and redraws itself when the data changes.
Think of a stateful widget as a scorekeeper in a game, constantly updating the score based on the game's progress.

title: Serverless Functions
subtext: Execute code without the need to manage servers
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Serverless Functions
texts: Serverless functions are pieces of code that are executed by a cloud provider without requiring the developer to manage a server or runtime environment.
Imagine serverless functions as a catering service that delivers food directly to your event, without you needing to cook or clean.

title: Edge Services
subtext: Technologies providing services closer to the user
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Edge Services
texts: Edge services are technologies that provide content, computing, and security to user devices at the edge of the network, closer to the user.
Think of edge services as local branches of a bank, offering faster and more personalized services than the main headquarters.

title: Dark Launch
subtext: Release features to a subset of users without their knowledge
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Dark Launch
texts: Dark launching is a technique where new features are released to a subset of users under real conditions without their knowledge.
Think of a dark launch as a soft opening for a restaurant, where new dishes are tested discreetly before the official menu launch.

title: Cloud Security
subtext: Procedures and technology to secure cloud environments
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Cloud Security
texts: Cloud security involves the procedures and technology that secure cloud computing environments against both external and internal cybersecurity threats.
Think of cloud security as the security measures at an airport, ensuring the safety of passengers and the integrity of flights.

title: Scalability
subtext: Capability of a system to handle growth
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Scalability
texts: Scalability is the capability of a system, network, or process to handle a growing amount of work, or its potential to accommodate growth.
Think of scalability as the ability of a bridge to handle more traffic as the city grows.

title: Event Stream Processing
subtext: Analyze and process continuous streams of events
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Event Stream Processing
texts: Event Stream Processing involves analyzing and processing a continuous flow of events in real-time to detect patterns, trends, or anomalies.
Imagine event stream processing as monitoring a live news feed and immediately reacting to any breaking stories.

title: Multi-Tenancy
subtext: Single instance of software serves multiple customers
author: Buzzpy

title: Software Containers
subtext: Package an application and its dependencies into a unit
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Software Containers
texts: Software containers package an application and its dependencies into a standardized unit for development, shipment, and deployment.
Think of containers as portable lunchboxes that hold everything needed for a meal, no matter where you eat it.

title: Cloud Orchestration
subtext: Automated arrangement and coordination of cloud services
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Cloud Orchestration
texts: Cloud Orchestration is the automated arrangement, coordination, and management of complex cloud services and processes.
Imagine cloud orchestration as a conductor directing an orchestra, ensuring each service plays its part in harmony.

title: Network Slicing
subtext: Create multiple virtual networks on shared infrastructure
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Network Slicing
texts: Network Slicing allows multiple virtual networks to be created on top of a shared physical infrastructure, each tailored for specific use cases.
Think of network slicing as dividing a highway into dedicated lanes for different types of vehicles.

title: IoT Edge Computing
subtext: Process data near its source in IoT devices
author: Buzzpy

title: Data Lakes and Warehouses Integration
subtext: Combine raw and structured data storage for better management
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Lakes and Warehouses Integration
texts: Integrating Data Lakes and Data Warehouses involves combining raw and structured data storage solutions for comprehensive data management.
Think of this integration as blending an unorganized library with a curated archive, offering both raw data and refined insights.

title: Machine Learning Operations (MLOps)
subtext: Streamline machine learning processes using DevOps principles
author: Buzzpy

title: Natural Language Processing
subtext: Enables computers to understand and process human language.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Natural Language Processing
texts: Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a field of artificial intelligence that helps computers understand and interact with human language. It's used in applications like chatbots and translation services.
NLP enables computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language.

title: Recurrent Neural Networks
subtext: Processes sequences of data, maintaining context over time.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Recurrent Neural Networks
texts: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) are a type of neural network designed for processing sequences of data, like time series or sentences. They have loops that allow information to persist across time steps.
RNNs are great for tasks where context from previous inputs is important.

title: Convolutional Neural Networks
subtext: Analyzes grid-like data, such as images, using filters.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Convolutional Neural Networks
texts: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are designed to process grid-like data, such as images. They use filters to detect patterns in different parts of an image, which helps in tasks like image classification.
CNNs are used for recognizing objects in photos or videos.

title: Autoencoders
subtext: Learns efficient data representations through compression and reconstruction.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Autoencoders
texts: Autoencoders are a type of neural network used for learning efficient representations of data. They work by compressing the input into a smaller representation and then reconstructing it to match the original input.
They are useful for tasks like noise reduction and dimensionality reduction.

title: Reinforcement Learning
subtext: Trains agents to make decisions by rewarding or punishing actions.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Reinforcement Learning
texts: Reinforcement Learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by receiving rewards or penalties. The goal is to maximize the total reward over time.
It's like training a robot to play a game by giving it points for making good moves and penalties for bad moves.

title: Transfer Learning
subtext: Adapts pre-trained models for new but related tasks.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Transfer Learning
texts: Transfer Learning is a technique where a pre-trained model is adapted to perform a different but related task. This approach helps save time and computational resources.
For example, a model trained to recognize cats and dogs can be adapted to identify different breeds of dogs.

title: Hyperparameter Tuning
subtext: Optimizes model settings to improve performance.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Hyperparameter Tuning
texts: Hyperparameter Tuning is the process of optimizing the settings of a machine learning model to improve its performance. These settings, called hyperparameters, control the learning process and the structure of the model.
It's like adjusting the knobs on a radio to get the best sound quality.

title: Cross-Validation
subtext: Evaluates model performance on multiple data splits.
author: Buzzpy

title: Feature Engineering
subtext: Creates or modifies features to enhance model performance.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Feature Engineering
texts: Feature Engineering involves creating new features or modifying existing ones to improve the performance of a machine learning model. It's like adding more details to a drawing to make it clearer.
Effective feature engineering can make a significant difference in how well a model performs.

title: Feature Scaling
subtext: Normalizes feature ranges for better model performance.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Feature Scaling
texts: Feature Scaling is the process of normalizing the range of features in your data. This helps improve the performance and convergence speed of machine learning algorithms.
It's like making sure all the pieces of a puzzle fit together properly.

title: Overfitting
subtext: When a model learns too much from training data, harming new data performance.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Overfitting
texts: Overfitting occurs when a machine learning model learns the details and noise in the training data to the extent that it negatively impacts its performance on new data.
It's like memorizing answers to a practice test without understanding the material, leading to poor performance on the actual exam.

title: Underfitting
subtext: When a model is too simple to capture the underlying data patterns.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Underfitting
texts: Underfitting happens when a machine learning model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern in the data. It performs poorly on both training and new data.
It's like using a very basic formula to solve a complex problem, resulting in inaccurate answers.

title: Regularization
subtext: Prevents overfitting by adding penalties to model complexity.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Regularization
texts: Regularization is a technique used to prevent overfitting by adding a penalty to the complexity of the model. It helps in keeping the model simpler and more generalizable.
It's like adding rules to limit how much a model can change to avoid fitting too closely to the training data.

title: Bagging
subtext: Combines predictions from multiple models for improved accuracy.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Bagging
texts: Bagging, or Bootstrap Aggregating, is an ensemble technique that improves model performance by training multiple models on different subsets of the data and combining their predictions.
It's like asking several people for their opinions and then averaging them to make a decision.

title: Boosting
subtext: Builds models sequentially, with each correcting errors of the previous one.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Boosting
texts: Boosting is an ensemble technique that builds multiple models sequentially, where each model tries to correct the errors of the previous one. The final prediction is a weighted sum of the predictions from all models.
It's like learning from mistakes and improving with each step.

title: Ensemble Methods
subtext: Combines multiple models to improve overall performance.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Ensemble Methods
texts: Ensemble Methods combine the predictions from multiple models to improve overall performance. Techniques like bagging, boosting, and stacking are common ensemble methods.
It's like using the wisdom of a group to make a better decision.

title: ROC Curve
subtext: Graphical representation of a classifier's performance.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: ROC Curve
texts: The ROC Curve (Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve) is a graphical representation of a classifier's performance. It plots the true positive rate against the false positive rate at various thresholds.
It helps in assessing how well a model can distinguish between classes.

title: AUC Curve
subtext: i.e. Area Under the Curve
author: Buzzpy

description.title: AUC Curve
texts: AUC (Area Under the Curve) is a performance measurement for classification problems at various threshold settings. The AUC represents the degree or measure of separability. It tells how much the model is capable of distinguishing between classes.
It's like checking how well a doctor can distinguish between patients with and without a disease based on a diagnostic test.

title: Precision and Recall
subtext: Metrics for evaluating classification model accuracy and completeness.
author: Buzzpy

title: F1 Score
subtext: Harmonic mean of Precision and Recall for balanced evaluation.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: F1 Score
texts: The F1 Score is a metric that combines Precision and Recall into a single number. It is the harmonic mean of Precision and Recall, providing a balanced measure of a model's accuracy.
It's useful when you need a single metric to assess the performance of a model.

title: Confusion Matrix
subtext: A table to evaluate classification model performance.
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Confusion Matrix
texts: A Confusion Matrix is a table used to evaluate the performance of a classification model. It shows the counts of true positive, false positive, true negative, and false negative predictions.
It helps in understanding the types of errors a model makes.

title: Cross-Entropy
subtext: Loss function measuring the difference between predicted and actual class labels.
author: Buzzpy

title: NoSQL Databases
subtext: Flexible, scalable data storage solutions
author: Buzzpy

title: Microservices Architecture
subtext: Independent, small service modules in software
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Microservices Architecture
texts: Microservices architecture is a way of building software where each part is a small, independent piece. It's like building a Lego structure with different blocks that can be replaced without breaking the whole thing.
Think of microservices as separate apps on your phone that work together to make everything run smoothly.

title: Serverless Architecture
subtext: Cloud management of server operations
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Serverless Architecture
texts: Serverless architecture means you don't have to manage servers yourself. The cloud provider takes care of it for you. It's like having a magic kitchen that cooks your food without you needing to know how.
Imagine serverless as a vending machine that automatically refills itself when something runs out.

title: WebAssembly (Wasm)
subtext: High-performance web applications
author: Buzzpy

title: Edge Computing
subtext: Data processing closer to data sources
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Edge Computing
texts: Edge computing brings data processing closer to where it's needed, reducing delays. It's like having a mini-computer in your smart devices to make things faster.
Imagine edge computing as a brain in your devices that helps them think quicker without asking a faraway server.

title: Zero Trust Security Model
subtext: Security that trusts no one by default
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Zero Trust Security Model
texts: Zero Trust is a security approach where no one inside or outside the network is trusted by default. It's like having multiple locks and security checks before letting someone in.
Think of Zero Trust as always double-checking and verifying everyone before allowing access to important stuff.

title: Docker Swarm
subtext: Management of Docker container clusters
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Docker Swarm
texts: Docker Swarm helps manage a group of Docker containers, making it easy to deploy, manage, and scale them. It's like having a team of workers that coordinate tasks efficiently.
Think of Docker Swarm as the conductor of an orchestra, ensuring all musicians play in harmony.

title: OAuth 2.0
subtext: Authorization framework for resource access
author: Buzzpy

title: JWT (JSON Web Tokens)
subtext: Securely transmit information as JSON
author: Buzzpy

title: Event-Driven Architecture
subtext: Building software with actions triggering responses
author: Buzzpy

title: CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation)
subtext: Separating read and write operations for efficiency
author: Buzzpy

title: DevSecOps
subtext: Integrating security into the DevOps process
author: Buzzpy

title: Data Lake
subtext: Vast storage for raw data in its native format
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Lake
texts: A Data Lake is a storage system that holds vast amounts of raw data in its native format. It's like having a giant pool where you can store all kinds of water without sorting.
Think of a Data Lake as a big swimming pool where you can store different types of data.

title: ETL (Extract, Transform, Load)
subtext: Process to collect, change, and store data
author: Buzzpy

title: Monolith
subtext: A single, large application handling multiple tasks
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Monolith
texts: A monolith is a large, single software application that handles multiple tasks. It's like having one big machine that does everything, from washing clothes to making coffee.
Imagine a monolith as an all-in-one tool that can be harder to fix if something breaks.

title: Data Warehouse
subtext: System for storing and managing large data for analysis
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Warehouse
texts: A Data Warehouse is a system used to store and manage large amounts of data for analysis. It's like a giant library where all the books are organized for easy searching.
Think of a Data Warehouse as a super-organized bookshelf that makes finding information quick and easy.

title: Graph Databases
subtext: Databases storing data in nodes and edges to show relationships
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Graph Databases (e.g., Neo4j)
texts: Graph Databases store data in nodes and edges, which show relationships. It's like a web of connections, like a social network map.
Imagine a Graph Database as a map of your friendships, showing who knows who.

title: APM (Application Performance Management)
subtext: Monitors and manages software application performance
author: Buzzpy

title: Infrastructure as Code (IaC)
subtext: Managing infrastructure through machine-readable scripts
author: Buzzpy

title: Immutable Infrastructure
subtext: Infrastructure that is never modified after deployment
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Immutable Infrastructure
texts: Immutable Infrastructure means servers are never modified after deployment; they're replaced with new ones. It's like using a new sheet of paper for each new drawing.
Imagine Immutable Infrastructure as using new Lego pieces each time you build something new.

title: Distributed Ledger Technology
subtext: Digital system recording transactions in multiple places simultaneously
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Distributed Ledger Technology
texts: Distributed Ledger Technology (DLT) is a digital system for recording transactions where details are recorded in multiple places at the same time. It's like having multiple copies of a book to prevent losing any information.
Think of DLT as sharing your diary with friends to ensure everyone has the same stories.

title: Chaos Engineering
subtext: Practice of testing systems to withstand turbulent conditions
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Chaos Engineering
texts: Chaos Engineering is the practice of experimenting on a system to build confidence in its ability to withstand turbulent conditions. It's like testing a bridge by simulating strong winds.
Imagine Chaos Engineering as stress-testing your structures to ensure they can handle unexpected events.

title: Reactive Programming
subtext: Handling data streams and changes in real time
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Reactive Programming
texts: Reactive Programming is a way to handle data streams and changes in real time. It's like making sure your app can react instantly to user inputs, like a game that updates immediately when you press a button.
Imagine Reactive Programming as being able to respond quickly to events, just like a reflex.

title: Data Sharding
subtext: Splitting a database into smaller, faster parts
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Sharding
texts: Data Sharding splits a large database into smaller, faster, more manageable parts. It's like cutting a big pizza into slices so everyone can have a piece.
Imagine data sharding as dividing your work among friends to get it done faster.

title: API Gateway
subtext: Manages requests and directs them to the correct services
author: Buzzpy

description.title: API Gateway
texts: An API Gateway is like a front door that handles all requests from clients, ensuring they get directed to the right services. It's like a receptionist who directs calls to the correct department.
Imagine an API Gateway as a helpful guide that makes sure everyone gets to where they need to go.

title: WebRTC (Web Real-Time Communication)
subtext: Enabling real-time communication directly in web browsers
author: Buzzpy

title: Data Governance
subtext: Management of data's availability, usability, integrity, and security
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Governance
texts: Data Governance is the management of data's availability, usability, integrity, and security. It's like making sure your library's books are organized, accessible, and protected.
Think of Data Governance as setting rules and responsibilities for handling data properly.

title: Data Anonymization
subtext: Removing personal identifiers from data to protect privacy
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Data Anonymization
texts: Data Anonymization removes personal information from data sets so that individuals can't be identified. It's like blurring faces in a photo to protect people's privacy.
Imagine Data Anonymization as making sure no one can recognize the people in your photos.

title: Federated Learning
subtext: Training AI models across multiple devices without sharing data
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Federated Learning
texts: Federated Learning is a way to train AI models across multiple devices without sharing raw data. It's like learning from everyone's notebooks without taking them away.
Imagine Federated Learning as combining knowledge from many sources while keeping the original notes private.

title: Explainable AI (XAI)
subtext: Making AI decisions understandable to humans
author: Buzzpy

title: Synthetic Data
subtext: Artificially generated data that mimics real data
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Synthetic Data
texts: Synthetic Data is artificially generated data that mimics real data. It's like creating a fake ID that looks real but isn't linked to a real person.
Imagine Synthetic Data as a practice exam that helps you prepare for the real test without using real questions.

title: Quantum Cryptography
subtext: Using principles of quantum mechanics for secure communication
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Quantum Cryptography
texts: Quantum Cryptography uses the principles of quantum mechanics to secure data. It's like using a secret code that only works with the laws of physics.
Imagine Quantum Cryptography as an unbreakable lock that can only be opened with a special quantum key.

title: Digital Twins
subtext: Virtual replicas of physical objects or systems
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Digital Twins
texts: Digital Twins are virtual replicas of physical objects or systems. It's like having a digital version of yourself that can try things out before you do.
Imagine Digital Twins as having a virtual clone to test new ideas without any risk.

title: Edge AI
subtext: Bringing artificial intelligence to edge devices to process data locally
author: Buzzpy

title: Homomorphic Encryption
subtext: Performing computations on encrypted data without decryption
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Homomorphic Encryption
texts: Homomorphic Encryption allows computations on encrypted data without decrypting it. It's like solving a puzzle without seeing the pieces.
Imagine Homomorphic Encryption as doing math with secret numbers that only make sense when you finish the calculation.

title: Fog Computing
subtext: Extending cloud computing to the edge of an enterprise's network
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Fog Computing
texts: Fog Computing extends cloud computing to the edge of the network, processing data closer to where it's generated. It's like having mini-clouds that work together with the big cloud.
Imagine Fog Computing as a network of small clouds that help process information locally.

title: Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)
subtext: Isolated cloud resources for enhanced security within a public cloud
author: Buzzpy

title: Hybrid Cloud
subtext: Combining public and private cloud environments for flexibility
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Hybrid Cloud
texts: Hybrid Cloud combines private and public clouds to provide greater flexibility. It's like having both a private garden and access to a public park.
Imagine Hybrid Cloud as using both your own secure space and a shared area for different needs.

title: Multi-Cloud Strategy
subtext: Using multiple cloud computing services to mitigate single-provider risks
author: Buzzpy

title: DataOps
subtext: An agile methodology for developing and maintaining data analytics
author: Buzzpy

title: Bioinformatics
subtext: Using technology to understand biological data
author: Buzzpy

description.title: Bioinformatics
texts: Bioinformatics combines biology, computer science, and information technology to analyze biological data. It's like using computers to understand life better.
Imagine Bioinformatics as a digital detective solving mysteries of living organisms.

title: GDPR
subtext: General Data Protection Regulation
author: Buzzpy

title: symmetric-cryptography
subtext: algorithms for cryptography that use the same cryptographic keys for both the encryption of plaintext.
author: Buzzpy

title: Asymmetric-cryptography
subtext: cryptographic scheme requiring two different keys, one for encryption and the other for decryption.
author: Buzzpy
